Write to Deepen Comprehension: Make a Chart

Have students make a chart that shows metric units of length and capacity. Have them list the name of each unit and draw a picture that illustrates the quantity of each one. For example, to show a liter, students can draw a liter bottle of water.
Then have students summarize the chart information in a paragraph.

Explain that a possessive noun shows ownership. To show that one person or thing owns something, add apostrophe s (s). Display Phonics/Syllable Card for support.
Add s to cat. Model for students how to read the new word formed (cats). Then provide a sample sentence: The cats tail is long.
Explain that to show more than one person or thing owns something, add an apostrophe () to a plural noun that ends in s.
Add  to cats. Model for students how to read the new word formed (cats). Provide a sample sentence: All of the cats tails are long.
Explain that for an irregular plural noun that does not end in s, add s to make it possessive.
Add s to men. Model for students how to read the new word formed (mens). Provide a sample sentence: All of the mens shoes got wet in the rain.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.

Read the title. Explain that this text asks questions that are riddles. Each riddle contains clues about the answer, which is always about a game.

For the first reading, you read the riddles and have students read the answer. Then switch roles and repeat for the second reading. Partners can switch roles during the rereadings: one reads the riddle and the other reads the answer.

High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the number of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

Review singular and plural possessive nouns.
Draw a ladder on the board.
Have students work together to write each word on the ladder rung.
can be added to nouns to form possessive nouns. Display the words
. Have students identify each word as a singular or plural possessive noun and explain how they know.
. Model how to form the possessive noun for each word and tell if the noun is singular or plural.
Have students select two of the possessive nouns and write sentences for them.
This word describes a very sharp object.
Change the first two letters of knife to form a word that is the opposite of husband.
Add an ending to make wife a singular possessive noun.
Change one letter and move the apostrophe in wifes to make a plural possessive noun.
Replace one letter in wives to form a word that is the possessive plural of a very sharp object.
Replace two letters in knives to form the plural possessive form of life.
Read, Build, Write: brought, contain, front, gave, inches, material, noun, ocean, strong, verb
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
